Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: A weekend stroll through the park passes posted no-littering signs and a nearby trash bin.
Story: As I strolled through the park on a bright Saturday morning, my phone buzzed with a message from my granddaughter. She’d just started her new job and wanted to share her excitement. I knew how important it was to keep in touch, to show her I cared and was proud of her. I stopped by a bench, eager to call her back, but noticed the “No Littering” signs and a trash bin just a few steps away. The bench was covered in crumbs and wrappers—someone else’s mess, but it bothered me. As a citizen, I felt a responsibility to keep the park clean, to set an example and respect the space we all shared. But as a grandparent, I didn’t want to delay my response and risk making my granddaughter feel unimportant. My phone vibrated again, her name lighting up the screen, while the litter on the bench seemed to glare at me, demanding action. I stood there, torn between picking up the trash and calling her right away, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
